The wind, the real Chicago wind they called the Hawk, was a bully. It shoved skyscrapers, screamed down alleyways, and tried to peel the sky off the lake. Up here, perched on the west antenna of the Willis Tower, it was a physical presence, a roaring beast made of air. Pip, however, was used to it. He leaned into the gale, his jacket—crafted from the supple leather of a shrew’s left glove—zipped tight to his chin. Below him, Chicago was a circuit board of pulsing, geometric light, a sprawling, beautiful, man-made galaxy. And it was his.

Not his in the way a king owns a kingdom, but his in the way a janitor owns his building. He knew its creaks and groans, its secret passages, its leaky faucets. The city was a living thing, and Pip was one of its tenders. He kept the magical wiring from shorting out. A pixie in the big city. A joke, if you told it to the old courts in the Glimmer, the Fae world he’d left behind. They had their dew-dappled glades and mushroom rings. Pip had a million watts of electricity, the rumble of the ‘L’ train, and the smell of roasting hot dogs that could find you from three blocks away. He figured he’d gotten the better deal.

A soft, warm pressure nudged his back. He didn’t need to look. “I know, I know, Barnaby. It’s cold.”

Barnaby bleated, a sound like cotton balls being pulled apart. He wasn't a sheep, not really. Not a cud-chewing, grass-munching creature of the field. Barnaby was made of sterner, stranger stuff. He was a cloud, a very dense and opinionated cloud that had, for reasons known only to the cosmos, decided to take the form of a particularly fluffy Horned Dorset sheep. His fleece was condensed morning fog, his eyes were two shiny drops of dew, and his horns were swirls of cirrus, hard as polished ice. Right now, he was huddled into a tight, woolly ball, trying to share his peculiar, internal warmth.

“Another hour, pal,” Pip said, patting the sheep’s flank. It felt like punching a pillow that was somehow also static electricity. “Then we can head down. Grab a bite. I’m thinking a discarded kernel of Garrett’s, the cheesy kind. Maybe a dropped crumb of a Portillo’s chocolate cake shake if we’re lucky.”

Barnaby responded by nudging him again, harder this time, and puffing a small, intricate cloud from his nose. The cloud briefly formed a perfect, tiny snowflake before dissipating in the wind. His way of saying, *It’s not the cold, you idiot.*

Pip straightened up, his own wings, iridescent and patterned like a Luna moth’s, giving a nervous flutter under his jacket. Barnaby was never wrong about this stuff. He was a barometer for the Veil, the shimmering, invisible membrane that separated the mundane world of humans from the wild, chaotic magic of the Glimmer. Pip scanned the city again, his gaze sharpening. He wasn't looking at the lights anymore. He was looking at the spaces *between* the lights.

Most nights, the Veil over Chicago was a patchwork quilt. It was thin over hospitals where life and death did their frantic dance, thick and sleepy over quiet residential streets, and thrummed like a guitar string over concert halls and sports stadiums. Pip’s job was to stitch up the little tears, the snags caused by bursts of human emotion—a lover’s quarrel, a stock market crash, the sheer joy of a home run at Wrigley Field. Simple stuff. Gremlins who liked to chew on fiber optic cables, Boggarts who’d get stuck in air-conditioning ducts, the occasional lost Kelpie who thought the Chicago River was a Scottish loch.

But this was different.

It wasn't a tear. It was a… sour note. A vibration in the very fabric of things, low and dissonant. It felt like a deep freezer opening in a hot room, a pocket of absolute, unnatural cold that had nothing to do with the wind. It was coming from the east, toward the lakefront. Near Millennium Park.

“Jeez,” Pip whispered, the word stolen by the gale. He’d felt things like this before, but rarely. It was the feeling of purposeful magic. Directed. Not the chaotic, messy spillage of human feeling, but the cold, sharp edge of a Fae will.

“Alright, fluff-butt. You win.” Pip swung a leg over Barnaby’s back, settling onto the surprisingly firm expanse of cloud-wool. “Let’s go see who’s messing with my town.”

With a grunt that was more of a whoosh, Barnaby launched them from the antenna. They didn’t fall. They glided. Barnaby was a master of the air currents, catching updrafts that swirled between the canyons of steel and glass, banking and turning with a grace that defied his sheepish form. The roar of the wind softened to a whistle in Pip’s ears. The city rushed up to meet them, the individual lights of cars becoming a flowing river of white and red. For a moment, even with the grim feeling in his gut, Pip felt the familiar thrill of it. This was flying. Not the gentle, flitting nonsense of his forest-bound cousins. This was a dive, a plummet, a controlled fall through the heart of a concrete giant.

They swooped low over the Pritzker Pavilion, its metal ribbons gleaming under the moon like a sleeping silver dragon. The cold spot was stronger here, a palpable deadness in the air. Barnaby landed with the softest of thuds on the plaza, his cloud-hooves making no sound on the granite. The place was deserted, save for the ever-present hum of the city and the distant wail of a siren. And in the center of the plaza, Cloud Gate—the Bean, as any real Chicagoan called it—sat like a giant, silent drop of mercury.

It was wrong. The Bean was supposed to reflect a funhouse-mirror version of the skyline, warping the proud towers into playful, silly shapes. But tonight, the reflection was sick. The lights of the buildings were smeared, their edges bleeding into a darkness that wasn’t just the absence of light. It was an active, hungry void. The reflection of the moon was a cracked and blackened disc.

“Okay,” Pip said, sliding off Barnaby’s back. “This is officially weird.”

Barnaby bleated nervously, stamping a hoof. A puff of vapor shaped like a skull drifted from his nose.

“Yeah, I get it. Very funny.”

Pip walked forward cautiously, his hand resting on the hilt of his weapon, a needle-sharp pin he’d liberated from a tailor’s shop on Jeweler’s Row. It was enchanted, of course. Sharp enough to pierce a goblin’s hide or sew a tear in reality. He reached the edge of the Bean and peered at his own reflection. It was him, but not. The pixie in the silver surface was gaunt, his eyes hollow sockets of shadow, his moth wings tattered and grey. A faint, oily blackness swirled around the image’s feet. Pip snatched his hand back as if burned.

The cold was emanating from a spot right beside the sculpture. At first, it looked like nothing, just a patch of air that was slightly darker than the surrounding night. But as Pip stared, his Fae senses tingling, it resolved into a shape. A rip. A jagged, three-foot-long tear in the world. It wasn't like the usual shimmering, gossamer frays he was used to mending. This was a wound. It was pitch black, and the edges didn’t shimmer, they crawled, like infinitesimally small, black insects were chewing at the fabric of the air. It smelled of static, of ozone, and something else… something ancient and rotten, like forgotten stars.

A fat city rat, probably on its way to feast on the contents of a nearby trash can, scurried a little too close to the rift. As it passed, its shadow, cast by the distant streetlights, stretched and pulled away from its body. The shadow writhed on the ground, deepening from grey to absolute black. It rose, peeling itself off the granite, a two-dimensional nightmare given a horrifying semblance of life. It had the rat's shape, but it was fluid, featureless, with pinpricks of red light for eyes. The real rat froze, squeaking in terror. The shadow-thing lunged.

“Oh no you don’t!” Pip yelled. He drew his pin-sword and flicked his wrist. A tiny spark of silver light shot from the tip and hit the shadow-rat mid-pounce. The creature dissolved with a faint hiss, like water on a hot skillet, and the air smelled of burnt hair. The real rat, seemingly unharmed, shook itself and scurried away into the night, having aged about ten years in three seconds.

Pip stood panting, his heart hammering against his ribs. He looked from his smoking pin to the ugly, black rift. He had never seen magic that could do that. Animate a shadow? Give it malice? This wasn’t some accidental spill from the Glimmer. This was an attack. This was a weapon.

He approached the rift again, more warily this time. He held out a hand, not touching it, but feeling the energy pouring from it. It was cold, draining, and it felt utterly devoid of life. It felt like an ending. He tried to summon the knowledge for a mending charm, the simple weaving of light and intention he’d used a thousand times. He drew a breath, focused his will, and began to chant the soft, clicking words of the Old Tongue.

The moment the magic left his lips, the rift reacted. A tendril of blackness, thin as a spider’s thread, lashed out and struck his fingertips. The pain was immediate and excruciating, a simultaneous burn and freeze. It felt like frostbite and a white-hot poker. Pip screamed, stumbling back and clutching his hand. Three of his fingers were blackened, the nails cracked, the skin numb and dead. The mending spell had shattered like glass. This dark magic didn't just resist his; it devoured it.

Barnaby rushed to his side, nudging the injured hand with his wet-dew nose, a low, worried bleat rumbling in his cloudy chest.

“I’m okay, I’m okay,” Pip gasped, though the throbbing in his hand told a different story. The blackness was already starting to recede, his own natural pixie vitality fighting back against the necrotic energy, but it was a slow and painful battle. He stared at the wound in the world, a visceral tear in the side of his city, and for the first time in a long time, Pip felt small. He was a janitor, and someone had just driven a tank through his lobby. This was so far beyond gremlins and boggarts it wasn't even on the same map. This was a declaration of war. He just had no idea against whom.

He looked from his blackened fingers to the malevolent tear in the world. The pain in his hand was more than just physical; it was an invasion. His own life force, a thing of moonlight and buzzing vitality, was actively at war with the creeping, dead-end nothingness that had seeped into his flesh. It was like trying to put out a fire with gasoline. He flexed his fingers, a wave of nausea rolling through him as the sensation returned, not as feeling, but as a deep, agonizing ache. Barnaby let out another low bleat, pushing his head firmly against Pip’s leg, a solid, warm anchor in a world that had suddenly gone sideways. The cloud-sheep’s dewdrop eyes were fixed on the rift, and a low hum, the sound of a distant thunderstorm, emanated from his woolly form.

“I know,” Pip breathed, cradling his injured hand. “We can’t leave it like this.” Leaving the rift open was like leaving a loaded gun in a playground. The shadow-rat was just a taste. What other horrors could crawl out of that sliver of anti-life? What if a child wandered through here on their way to school in the morning? The thought sent a jolt of ice through him that had nothing to do with the invading magic. He couldn't stitch it closed, but that didn't mean he was helpless. If you can’t fix a burst pipe, you shut off the main. You contain the damage.

He took a deep breath, ignoring the throbbing in his hand, and knelt on the cold granite. He closed his eyes, not to chant, but to listen. He reached out with his senses, past the unnatural cold of the rift, and tapped into the city itself. He felt the hum of the massive transformers buried deep beneath the streets, the constant flow of data through fiber-optic lines, the residual energy of a million footsteps that crossed this plaza every day. He felt the iron in the rebar skeletons of the skyscrapers, the latent electricity in the air, the very grid of the city's layout. This was his magic, the kind the Glimmer courts would never understand. Not a magic of twisting nature, but of co-opting and harmonizing with the vast, chaotic, beautiful systems of man.

“Okay, Chicago,” he whispered to the ground. “Help me out here. Lend me a little juice.” He placed his good hand flat on the paving stone. A faint blue light traced the grout lines around him, spreading out in a circuit-like pattern. He pulled, not with force, but with a gentle, insistent persuasion. He coaxed a sliver of power from the grid, borrowing the echo of wi-fi signals, guiding the faint magnetic fields that clung to the steel deep underground. The air around the black rift began to shimmer, not with Fae light, but with a faint, technological haze, like heat-blur over asphalt. Strands of pale blue energy, thin as copper wire, rose from the ground and began to weave themselves into a cage around the tear. It was a messy, desperate piece of work, a jury-rigged fence of pure city energy. The rift seemed to push against it, the darkness within roiling, but the cage held, humming with contained power.

Pip slumped, sweat beading on his brow despite the biting wind. The effort had drained him, leaving him feeling hollowed out and shaky. The blue cage flickered, and he knew it was a temporary fix, a magical tourniquet at best. It might last the night. It might not. But it was time. He looked at the distorted, sick reflection in the Bean, at the humming cage he’d built around the wound in his world. The janitor had just put a ‘Wet Floor’ sign in front of an abyss. It felt both profoundly heroic and utterly, laughably inadequate.

“Come on, Barnaby,” he said, his voice ragged. He climbed wearily onto the cloud-sheep’s back. “We need help.” Barnaby gave a soft grunt of agreement and leaped into the air, not with their earlier thrilling abandon, but with a careful, steady ascent. As they rose, the city no longer looked like a beautiful, sprawling galaxy to Pip. It looked fragile. Vulnerable. A delicate web of light and life with a spider of absolute darkness now sitting at its center. The joy of the flight was gone, replaced by a grim urgency. There was only one person he could think of who dealt in magic this old, this obscure. Someone who hoarded knowledge the way a dragon hoards gold.

“Time to pay a visit to the Underside,” Pip muttered into the wind, his injured hand a cold, throbbing reminder of his failure. “Let’s go see the Librarian.”

The Underside wasn’t a place you found on a map. It was a layer of the city, a rumor whispered in concrete. They descended, Barnaby shrinking his form to navigate the narrow spaces, his glorious fleece becoming a dense, compact ball of fog that barely brushed the greasy walls. Pip guided them down past the glittering penthouses, below the rumbling tracks of the ‘L’, and into the grimy, multi-layered labyrinth of Lower Wacker Drive. Up above, the city was a symphony of light and purpose; down here, it was a discordant hum, the city’s unconscious mind. The air tasted of damp earth, car exhaust, and the slow, cold breath of the river. Sodium-vapor lamps cast a perpetual, sickly orange twilight, making monsters of shadows and secrets of every dripping alcove.

Barnaby’s cloud-hooves were silent, but his passage disturbed things. Bloated, colorless sewer sprites scattered from his path, their gossamer wings stained with oil. A trio of rust-furred ferrets with too many eyes watched them pass from atop a junction box before melting back into the shadows. This was the other side of Pip’s janitorial duties, the plumbing and foundation of his building. He knew these passages as well as he knew the currents around the skyscrapers. He led them deeper, into a section where the streetlights had long since burned out, a dead-end tunnel choked with debris and forgotten municipal junk. The only light was the faint, internal luminescence that bled from Barnaby’s wool.

They stopped before a sheer concrete wall, a canvas of overlapping graffiti so thick it had formed a new, cratered surface. To a human, it was the end of the line. To Pip, it was a doorway. He slid from Barnaby’s back and approached the wall, placing his good hand on a faded spray-painted image of a crowned rat. He closed his eyes and didn't speak a spell, but a story. It was the price of entry. One must always give a piece of forgotten truth to the keeper of it. “There was a silver locket,” Pip whispered, his voice barely audible over a distant drip. “Fell from a purse on the Michigan Avenue bridge in the spring of ’88. It held a picture of a soldier and a single strand of blonde hair. It’s still down there, half-buried in the silt, waiting for someone who will never come back.”

For a moment, nothing happened. Then, the graffiti began to swirl. Colors ran like wet paint, and the concrete itself seemed to lose its solidity, becoming a shimmering curtain of grey dust. The air that washed out from the opening was cool and dry, carrying the scent of millennia of accumulated dust and brittle, yellowed paper. It was the smell of stillness, of knowledge left to steep in silence. Barnaby gave a hesitant bleat, but Pip patted his side reassuringly. “He’s expecting us.”

They stepped through the veil of concrete into a space that should not have been possible. They stood on a narrow stone balcony overlooking an abyss of impossible scale. Shelves stretched down into the darkness and up into a gloom so profound it might as well have been a starless sky. They were filled not just with books, but with scrolls tied in leather, stacks of clay tablets, reels of film, humming hard drives linked by nests of glowing cables, and shimmering glass spheres that held captured memories like fireflies in a jar. Walkways and spiral staircases of rusted iron and petrified wood crisscrossed the chasm, connecting islands of knowledge in the vast, silent sea. This was the Great Library of Chicago, the Underside’s most dangerous and valuable secret.

From the gloom below, something stirred. It was not a sound of movement, but of assembly. Piles of what looked like discarded newspapers and brittle manuscripts began to shift and gather, pulled together by an unseen force. The mass rose, compacting and forming into a towering, humanoid shape. It stood a good fifteen feet tall, its body a dense collage of printed words and forgotten ledgers, its limbs thick bundles of rolled blueprints. Its head was a blocky mass of encyclopedias, and two thick lenses from a pair of antique spectacles glowed with a soft, analytical light from within the paper face. This was the Librarian, an archival golem bound to collect and guard the city’s lost information.

“Your bio-signature is agitated, Pixie,” the Librarian’s voice rumbled, a sound like a thousand pages turning at once. “And you are leaking necrotic energy onto my welcome mat. Explain.” The golem did not move from its spot, but its lens-eyes swiveled and zoomed, focusing on Pip’s injured hand with unnerving precision.

Pip didn’t waste time with pleasantries; the Librarian had no use for them. He held up his blackened fingers. “I found a rift. Near the lakefront. It fought back.” The golem’s head tilted, a slight rustle of dry paper accompanying the motion. It extended a hand made of tightly bound phone books, and a single finger, a rolled-up land deed from the 1920s, pointed at Pip’s injury. “Void-taint. Unrefined, but potent. Animate shadow constructs?” Pip nodded grimly. “It peeled the shadow off a rat.” The Librarian’s lenses dimmed for a second, as if it were accessing some internal file. “This is not a chaotic spill from the Glimmer. This is a tool. A weapon. Its source signature is not in my index.”

“That’s why I’m here,” Pip said, his voice tight. “I need to know what it is. What can make a wound like that in the Veil. And how to close it for good.” The Librarian stood motionless for a long time, the only sound the faint hum of its internal workings. The silence in the chasm was absolute, a pressure on the ears. “The information you seek is not indexed under ‘general knowledge’,” it finally rasped. “It resides in the Restricted Archives. Access requires a significant price.” Barnaby shuffled his hooves nervously, the static in his fleece crackling audibly. Pip steeled himself. “What do you want?”

“I have a billion facts, but very few experiences,” the Librarian stated. Its glowing eyes fixed on Pip. “Your magic is an anomaly. A symbiosis with a human construct. I wish to understand the sensory input of your flight. Not the physics, not the Fae mechanics. The *feeling*. The moment you dive from the antenna, the city lights below you, the wind, the thrill. Give me that memory. All of it. In exchange, I will grant you access for one hour.”

A memory of flight. It was the purest thing Pip owned. Not a deed, not a title, but a feeling. It was the giddy, stomach-dropping lurch of a dive, the triumphant roar of the wind, the moment the world resolved from a blur of motion into a tapestry of perfect, crystalline light. It was the very essence of his freedom, the trade he’d made for a world of damp forests and cloying, ancient traditions. To give that away felt like giving up a lung. It was a mutilation.

Barnaby seemed to understand. He pressed his dense, foggy body hard against Pip’s legs, his internal storm rumbling a clear protest. *Don’t do it.* Pip looked from the solid, loyal form of his friend to his own blackened, useless fingers. The dull ache was a constant reminder of the gaping wound in the city, humming with malevolence under its temporary cage. The memory was his joy. The city was his purpose. A janitor doesn’t get to keep the penthouse view if the boiler is about to explode. With a sigh that felt like it was tearing something loose inside him, Pip gave the Librarian a curt nod. “Fine. You have a deal.”

The Librarian’s head tilted, the paper rustling. “The transaction will be… direct.” It raised its massive hand of phone books and ledgers. The paper fingers unfurled, and from the palm, a single, smooth, blank sheet of vellum slid forward. “Place your uninjured hand upon the page. And remember.” Pip swallowed hard, a knot of dread tightening in his chest. He looked at Barnaby, trying to convey a reassurance he didn’t feel. “Stay here, pal. This won’t take a second.” He stepped forward and pressed his palm against the offered sheet. It was cool and unnervingly smooth, like touching still water. He closed his eyes and did as he was told. He remembered.

He was on the antenna again, the Hawk screaming in his ears. He leaped. The memory flooded him—the exhilarating drop, the surge of power as his wings caught the updraft, the city sprawling below him like a fallen constellation. But this time, it was different. A cold, clinical awareness overlaid the joy. He felt the memory being copied, dissected. The elation was catalogued as *neurochemical response 7.3*. The breathtaking view was broken down into quantifiable data: *2.1 million discrete light sources, average lumen intensity 80-120*. The feeling of the wind was reduced to *barometric pressure and vector analysis*. The pure, untranslatable bliss of flight was being translated, and in the translation, it was being murdered. The memory that returned to him was a ghost, a faded photograph of a moment that had once been brilliantly alive. He was left with the facts of the flight, but the feeling, the heart of it, was gone.

Pip pulled his hand back as if from a fire, stumbling away from the golem. He felt hollow, scoured out. The Librarian, however, seemed to vibrate with a new energy. A single page of Emily Dickinson’s poetry detached itself from its shoulder and fluttered to the stone floor. Its lens-eyes glowed brighter than before. “Data received. Fascinating. Inefficient, but… evocative.” The golem turned, its body moving with a ponderous grace. “Your hour has begun. The Restricted Archives are now open.” With a grinding sound of stone on stone, a section of shelves behind the Librarian swung inward, revealing a dark, narrow passage that seemed to absorb the light. The air that drifted out was colder than the void-taint, thick with the weight of dangerous, sleeping things.

Pip took a shaky breath, shoving the feeling of violation down deep. He had a job to do. He gestured for Barnaby, who trotted to his side, his fleece crackling with anxious energy. Together, they stepped into the passage. The change was immediate. The vast, orderly silence of the main library was replaced by a cacophony of whispers. The shelves here were not neat but crooked and menacing, carved from bone and dark, oily wood. The books were bound in more than just leather; some were covered in what looked like cured reptile skin, others in metal plates that were cold to the touch, and one entire shelf seemed to be bound in solidified darkness that drank the light from Barnaby’s wool.

This was a library of secrets that wanted to stay secret. As Pip passed a row of iron-bound tomes, one of them snapped at him like a dog, its pages parting to reveal rows of razor-sharp vellum teeth. Further down, a scroll unrolled itself slightly, whispering a tempting lie about a way to restore his blighted fingers that he knew would lead to madness. Barnaby bleated and shied away from a collection of glass spheres that showed not memories, but futures, all of them ending in screams. Pip kept his good hand resting on his pin-sword and the other tucked into his jacket, focusing his Fae senses, searching for a resonance that matched the awful, life-draining cold of the rift. He pushed past the seductive, the angry, the insane, looking for the quiet, hungry rot he now knew so intimately.

He found it in a small, forgotten alcove, on a shelf all by itself. It was a single, thin volume, no larger than his hand. The book was bound in something that felt like dried skin but was as black and cold as interstellar space. It had no title. As Pip reached for it, the whispers in the archive fell silent. The air grew heavy. Barnaby backed away, a genuine puff of fearful smoke, shaped like a wilting flower, escaping his nose. Pip ignored the warning signs. This was it. The book’s cold was a perfect match for the energy that had wounded him. He braced himself and opened it.

The pages were not paper but thin sheets of pressed shadow, and the words on them crawled and shifted, refusing to be read. They were written in a dialect of the Old Tongue so archaic it was barely recognizable, a language of endings and decay. He had to squint, focusing his will, forcing the letters to hold still for a moment at a time. He scanned the writhing text, searching for anything about rifts or tears. He found a chapter heading that coalesced out of the darkness: *On the Shaping of Nothing*. His blood ran cold. This wasn't a book about mending. It was a manual. He read a passage, his lips moving silently, translating the vicious, spidery script. It spoke of the Veil not as a barrier to be maintained, but as a canvas to be torn. It described how to weaponize emptiness, how to spin shadow into a blade, how to give hunger a physical form. It was a textbook for the magic that had attacked him. And at the bottom of the page, beneath a diagram of a spiraling, devouring rune, was a name. It was the name of the practitioners, the artists of this entropic school of Fae magic. The Hollow.

A deep, rumbling groan echoed through the archives, the sound of the Librarian’s stone door beginning to close. His hour was almost up. Pip stared at the name, at the crawling, hateful words. He wasn’t just dealing with a monster or a magical accident. He was dealing with a Fae faction, a cult of artists whose medium was annihilation. This changed everything. This wasn't a leaky faucet anymore. Someone was trying to demolish his building, and they had the blueprints. He carefully closed the book, the feeling of its cold cover a brand against his palm, and with Barnaby huddled close, he hurried back toward the fading light of the main library, his mind racing. The Hollow. He had a name. And in a city of millions, a name was a place to start.

## Chapter 2

The groan of stone was a final, dismissive sound as the entrance to the Restricted Archives sealed itself, plunging the passage back into absolute darkness. The sudden silence was a relief, but the echoes of the whispering books still seemed to crawl along Pip’s skin. He felt the Librarian’s lens-eyes on him as he and Barnaby stepped back onto the main balcony, the vast, ordered chasm of shelves a stark contrast to the chaotic malignancy he had just witnessed. The golem hadn't moved, a mountain of silent paper and ink.

“Transaction complete,” its voice rustled, devoid of curiosity or concern. “Your biological readings have stabilized, though the necrotic scarring on your appendage appears permanent. A fascinating data point.” It was like a doctor telling a patient their tumor was a lovely shade of magenta. The sheer, inhuman indifference of the creature was a cold slap, and in that moment, Pip felt the hollow space in his mind where the joy of flight used to be. It was a raw, empty ache, and the Librarian’s words were the salt grinding into it.

“Keep your data points,” Pip snapped, his voice sharper than he intended. He swung himself onto Barnaby’s back, the familiar motion now feeling clumsy and mundane. There was no anticipatory thrill, no surge of freedom. There was only the dull weight of his body and a job to do. Without a word, he nudged Barnaby toward the shimmering curtain of concrete that served as the entrance. They passed through the wall, leaving the scent of dust and silence behind, and re-entered the damp, orange-lit gloom of Lower Wacker Drive. The mundane smells of wet concrete and old exhaust fumes had never been so welcome.

Barnaby let out a low, shaky bleat and nudged Pip’s injured hand, which he still had cradled against his chest. Pip unfurled his fingers to inspect the damage. The Librarian had been right. The blackness had receded from the surface, but the taint had left its mark. Three of his fingers were now a pale, ashen grey, the skin unnaturally smooth, and thin, dark lines, like cracked porcelain, webbed out from his knuckles. When he flexed them, they moved sluggishly, and a deep, phantom cold radiated from the bone. It was a scar, a permanent brand from the Hollow. A reminder of what they were, and what they could do. A part of the void, now a part of him.

He guided Barnaby upward, through the layers of the city’s guts, until they emerged into the open air of a crisp, pre-dawn Chicago. They settled on the iron trusses of the LaSalle Street bridge, the wind coming off the river cold and clean. Across the water, the hulking art deco fortress of the Merchandise Mart slept, and beyond it, the sky was beginning to soften from pitch black to a deep, bruised purple. The city was quiet, resting. And vulnerable. Pip looked at his scarred hand, then back at the sprawling grid of his home. A name. *The Hollow*. It was a thread, but Pip had no idea what part of the city’s vast, tangled sweater it belonged to. He was a mender, a repairman. He knew circuits and ley lines, not Fae political factions and death cults.

There were places, of course. Back in the Glimmer, there were courts and councils that dealt with this sort of thing. But he’d burned those bridges, trading their starlight and intrigue for asphalt and electricity. And he couldn’t risk opening a formal channel; it would be an invitation for the old courts to meddle, to see Chicago not as a place to be protected, but as a territory to be claimed. He needed local knowledge. The kind of gritty, street-level information that didn't get filed away in the Librarian's sterile archives. He needed to talk to someone who dealt not in pure facts, but in rumors, grudges, and secrets.

“Alright, fluff-butt,” he sighed, the sound weary. “Change of plans. No Garrett’s tonight.” He gave Barnaby a scratch behind his cirrus horns. “We’re going to see Silas.” Barnaby’s ears, two wisps of denser fog, twitched. He knew the name. He didn’t like it. Silas was nobody’s friend and everybody’s last resort. A purveyor of cursed artifacts, forgotten trinkets, and, for the right price, dangerously accurate information.

Their flight west was a grim, joyless thing. Pip kept them low, skimming over the dark, still river, the water reflecting the city lights in long, shimmering strokes. He saw it all with a janitor's eye now, a checklist of potential problems. The shadows beneath the Kinzie Street railroad bridge seemed too deep, too motionless. A flicker of movement in an alley off Wells Street wasn't a cat or a raccoon, but something that slithered without a body. He realized with a sickening lurch that he was seeing the world through the Hollow's lens—not as a living system, but as a series of vulnerabilities, places to break, to tear, to unmake. They were already here. The rift at the Bean wasn’t their first move; it was just their loudest.

They landed in a narrow, trash-strewn alley in the West Loop, a neighborhood of old warehouses rapidly being converted into expensive lofts and trendy restaurants. Tucked between a Michelin-starred eatery and a CrossFit gym was a grimy, uninviting storefront. The window was thick with dust, displaying a motley collection of junk: a tarnished silver tea set, a mannequin hand draped with beaded necklaces, a stack of warped vinyl records. The only sign was a single, flickering neon word: “FINDS.” To the mundane eye, it was a failing pawn shop. To those who knew, it was the office of one of the most well-informed and ill-tempered creatures in Chicago.

Pip slid off Barnaby’s back, his boots crunching on broken glass. “Stay out here and try to look like a piece of abstract art,” he instructed the cloud-sheep. Barnaby responded by compacting himself into the shape of a lumpy, discarded armchair, a form he often adopted when trying to be inconspicuous. Pip took a deep breath, the phantom cold in his hand seeming to pulse with the rhythm of his anxious heart. He pushed open the heavy wooden door, triggering not a cheerful jingle, but a low, discordant chime that sounded like a cracked wine glass being struck by a fork. The air inside was thick with the smell of dust, tarnished metal, and something else—the faint, sharp scent of ozone and bottled time.

## Chapter 3

The inside of the shop was a physical assault on the senses. The discordant chime of the bell died, leaving a silence so thick it felt like cotton in the ears, punctuated only by the frantic, unsynchronized ticking of at least a dozen clocks. The air was a layered concoction of smells: the dry, papery scent of the Librarian’s archives overlaid with the acrid tang of aerosol polish, the sweet decay of wilting flowers, and the sharp, electric hum of caged lightning. Piles of forgotten objects rose like mountain ranges in the gloom, canyons of clutter forming narrow pathways between them. A taxidermied owl with mismatched button eyes stared down from a stack of National Geographics; a row of disembodied mannequin heads wore hats from every decade of the last century; a glass case held what looked like a collection of human teeth, each one meticulously labeled with a name and a date. It wasn't a mess; it was a fortress, each piece of junk a carefully placed brick in a wall of misdirection.

“If you’re going to leak despair all over my floor, at least buy something.” The voice was a dry rasp, like sandpaper on old wood. It came from behind a massive, cluttered counter that served as the shop's heart. A figure emerged from the shadows, not rising, but simply… resolving, as if he’d been part of the clutter all along. He was a small, wizened man with a bald head fringed by a wreath of shocking white hair. His face was a roadmap of deep-set wrinkles, and he wore a pair of tiny, circular spectacles perched on the end of a long, pointed nose. But it was his eyes that held Pip’s attention. They were the color of wet slate and held an ancient, transactional stillness. This was Silas.

He leaned forward, his elbows making a soft thump on the wood, and peered at Pip over his glasses. His gaze immediately fell to Pip’s injured hand. A slow, thin-lipped smile spread across his face, a crack appearing in a stone facade. “Well now. That’s a souvenir and a half. Looks like you tried to mend a hole in the world with your bare hands and found out the world bites back. Void-taint. Haven’t seen a fresh case of that in this city since the ‘68 convention. You’ve been busy.”

Pip felt a flush of anger at the creature's casual, predatory assessment of his wound. He had no time for games, for the intricate dance of leverage and favor that Silas so enjoyed. “I need information, Silas,” he said, his voice flat. “A Fae faction. They call themselves The Hollow.”

The smile on Silas’s face vanished. The stillness returned to his eyes, but now it was the stillness of a predator that has heard a larger, more dangerous animal nearby. He took off his spectacles and began to polish them with a grimy cloth, his movements slow and deliberate. For a long moment, he said nothing, the only sounds the manic ticking of the clocks and the distant rumble of a sanitation truck in the alley. "Never heard of them," he finally said, the lie as thin and brittle as old glass. "Sounds like a Glimmer problem. Take it back to the old country."

“They’re here,” Pip insisted, stepping closer to the counter, the faint glow from the streetlights catching the ashen grey of his fingers. “They opened a rift by the Bean. This,” he held up his hand, “is what they do. It’s not a Glimmer problem, it’s a Chicago problem. It’s my problem. And that makes it your problem, Silas. Bad for business when the city gets unmade.”

Silas placed his glasses back on his nose, his slate-grey eyes boring into Pip. “Information about things that unmake has a commensurate price. It’s expensive. Very.” He gestured around the shop with a sweep of his bony hand. “As you can see, I am a purveyor of tangible assets. I don’t trade in whispers and promises. I require payment.”

“What do you want?” Pip asked, his heart sinking. He had nothing of value, nothing Silas would want. His pin-sword was his own, his jacket was shrew’s leather, and the last valuable thing he’d possessed, a feeling, was now a dead file in a golem’s memory banks. Silas seemed to read his thoughts. “Oh, I don’t want anything you *have*, pixie. I want something you can *get*.” He leaned forward again, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. “The Chicago Theatre. Its vertical sign, the big one. There's a lightbulb on the upper curve of the ‘C’ that’s been dying for a week. Tonight, just before the sun rises, it will give its last flicker. I want that flicker. Its final photon. Its death rattle. Bring it to me, contained, and I’ll tell you what I know.”

The request was so bizarre, so quintessentially *Silas*, that Pip could only stare. To capture the death of a light, a tiny ending among a million others in the city. It was the kind of esoteric, poetic nonsense that powered the strange engines of urban magic. It was also a task that required speed, stealth, and a complete disregard for the laws of physics—a job tailor-made for a pixie. He looked at his scarred hand, the cold of it a constant, throbbing counterpoint to the city’s pulse. He thought of the rift, caged but not cured, a cancer in the heart of his home. He had no choice. “You’ll get your flicker,” he said, the words tasting like ash. “You’ll need a container,” Silas said, his smile returning. He reached under the counter and produced a small glass vial, no bigger than Pip’s thumb, stoppered with a cork. He slid it across the dusty surface. It was cool to the touch, and the glass seemed to ripple, as if it were made of captured moonlight.

Once Pip had pocketed the vial, Silas leaned back, satisfied. “The Hollow,” he began, his voice taking on the quality of a lecturer. “They’re not a court. They’re a philosophy. He closed his eyes and reached out, not to the building, but to the space around it. ## Chapter 5

The Uptown Theatre was a fortress of forgotten grandeur, and its defenses were time and neglect. The main doors were clad in thick, graffiti-covered plywood, impenetrable to anything less than a sledgehammer. But a janitor knows a building has more than one door. Pip left Barnaby huddled in the shadow of a boarded-up check-cashing store, the cloud-sheep having condensed himself into the form of a particularly sad-looking pile of discarded tires. “If they come out, don’t be a hero. Be the wind,” Pip whispered, giving the top “tire” a pat. Barnaby responded with a low, almost inaudible hum, a promise and a warning.

Pip took to the air, the flight a graceless, functional necessity. He skirted the building’s decaying façade, his eyes scanning for a weakness. He found one high up, a single broken pane in a magnificent, fan-shaped window above the dead marquee. It was a small, jagged mouth in the theatre’s stone face, an invitation he couldn’t refuse. He slipped through the opening, the edges of the broken glass sharp and menacing, and found himself in the theatre’s cavernous grand lobby. And the world went silent.

The silence was a physical thing. It was a pressure on his eardrums, a thick, smothering blanket woven from decades of dust and a deeper, more profound emptiness. Outside, the city roared with life; in here, sound came to die. The vast space was a cathedral of decay. Moonlight from the high windows illuminated a scene of breathtaking ruin. A double staircase, grand enough for royalty, swept upwards, its marble steps carpeted in a thick, grey silt that wasn’t dust but its ghost, a substance that seemed to absorb all vibration. Gilded plasterwork, depicting cherubs and musical muses, drooped from the vaulted ceiling, their joyful faces obscured by cobwebs as thick as cotton shrouds. Two colossal chandeliers, their crystal pendants clouded and dull, hung like executed aristocrats. Pip’s boots made no sound on the floor. He took a single, deliberate step, expecting an echo, a whisper of the room’s former glory. Nothing. The sound was simply gone, swallowed by the profound, narrative void. The cold in his scarred fingers pulsed in time with his hammering heart. This was their studio.

He drew his pin-sword, its silver tip a lonely spark of light in the oppressive gloom. He had to find them, to see what they were doing. He let the phantom cold in his hand be his guide, a morbid compass pointing him toward the heart of the rot. He moved through the lobby, a tiny, living thing in a vast mausoleum, past the skeletal remains of a concession stand, its glass cases cracked and empty. He passed a row of tarnished brass frames that should have held posters of glamorous film stars; the glass was intact, but the posters within were blank, their images and words leeched away, leaving behind nothing but yellowed, empty paper. The Hollow didn't just break things; they un-wrote them.

As he neared the immense, arching doorways that led to the auditorium, he sensed movement. He darted behind a thick, velvet-draped pillar, the fabric crumbling to grey ash at his touch. Two figures slid from the deeper shadows of the stairwell. They were not Fae, not exactly. They were shadows, but not the mindless, animalistic things from the Bean. These were tall, slender, and wore the vague outline of tailored coats and sharp hats, like specters of 1940s detectives. They moved with a silent, fluid grace, their forms shifting and unstable at the edges. They were guards, patrols woven from the theatre’s deepest, darkest corners. They swept the lobby with an unnatural awareness, their featureless heads turning, and for a moment, Pip was certain they had sensed him. He held his breath, pressing himself into the crumbling pillar, willing himself to be just another piece of the decay. The shadow-guards glided past, their passage leaving a trail of intense cold, and disappeared into the gloom on the far side of the lobby.

Pip waited until the cold receded before darting toward the auditorium doors. One of the massive, ornate doors was slightly ajar, a vertical sliver of even deeper darkness beyond it. The cold emanating from it was immense, a torrent of silent, negative energy. This was the nexus. Taking a deep, steadying breath, he peered through the gap. The sight stole the air from his lungs. He was looking into the main auditorium, a staggering abyss that once sat over four thousand people. The seats rose in sweeping tiers into a darkness so complete it felt infinite. But the stage… the stage was alive with a sickening, negative light.

In the center of the vast stage, two figures stood, their backs to him. They were Fae, unmistakably so, but twisted, desiccated. They were tall and impossibly thin, dressed in stark, modern, perfectly tailored clothes of charcoal grey and black. They moved with the unhurried, precise grace of surgeons or watchmakers, their focus absolute. Between them, suspended in the air, was the source of the unnatural light and the deafening silence. It was a spinning vortex of pure, concentrated nothingness, a spiral of anti-light that greedily drank the very gloom of the theatre. And orbiting it, like horrific planets, were shimmering, semi-transparent images—the sorrows they had harvested. He saw a woman’s face, contorted in terror, ripped from the chaos of the Eastland disaster. He saw the slow, unending grief of a mother standing over a small, dirt-caked grave in Graceland. ## Chapter 8

Staggering to his feet, his body a trembling vessel for a power that should have atomized him, Pip looked at the Fae across the water. He let the wild, chaotic fury of the storm-tossed surface flow past him and reached deeper, into the lake’s older, colder, heavier memories. He pulled on the crushing, inexorable pressure of the abyssal plain, the silent, patient weight of a hundred trillion tons of water that had ground mountains into sand. The air around the two Fae on their shrinking island of black water grew thick, then heavy. Their effortlessly elegant forms, which defied gravity, suddenly seemed to weigh a thousand pounds. The female Fae faltered, her arm lowering, her perfect posture broken by a force she could not see. The male staggered, his knees buckling under an invisible weight that had never before touched him. Pip pushed, pouring the very concept of pressure into the world around them. The Fae were creatures of air and will, of starlight and thought. They were being subjected to the crushing physics of the deep, a pressure that could implode a submarine, a gravity that could bend steel. A fine web of cracks appeared on the male Fae’s sculpted cheek, not from a blow, but from the sheer, immense weight of reality being forced upon his idealized form. The artists of emptiness, for the first time, were being made to feel the unbearable weight of the world they so casually sought to erase.

The male Fae’s mental voice, which had stabbed into Pip’s mind with such cold clarity, was now a fractured, desperate hiss, laced with a new and unfamiliar emotion: disbelief. *“This is… incorrect. The medium is fighting back. It is crude. It is… heavy.”* The very concept of weight was an insult to their philosophy, a vulgar, physical truth that their art was meant to transcend. He tried to raise a hand, to weave a new strand of silence, but his arm moved with the speed of a man wading through hardening concrete. The cracks on his face spread, a fine tracery of failure spiderwebbing across his perfect, empty beauty. He was an idea, and he was being broken by a fact.

Pip saw their struggle, their disbelief, and it fed his righteous fury. He looked from their faltering forms to Barnaby, who lay in a broken heap, the hole in his chest a sickening vortex of anti-life, his faint, internal glow sputtering like a dying ember. The sight was a hot poker to Pip’s heart. He screamed again, a raw, ragged sound that was half his own, half the lake's, and he pushed. He didn't just apply the pressure; he focused it. The churning, turquoise-glowing water around the Fae responded to his will. Two massive waves rose from the lake, not as crashing breakers, but as two immense, liquid hands, their watery fingers tipped with the cold, hard memory of glacial ice. They rose high over the Fae, dripping with the weight of eons, and began to close.

She threw her head back and shrieked, a sound that was not mental but horribly, physically real, a high, thin tearing of the air. As she did, her own form began to dissolve, not into nothingness, but into a swarm of infinitesimally small, black motes, like a cloud of ink or biting flies. The swarm shot upward, a chaotic cloud of pure malice, trying to flee the crushing grip of the lake.

The male Fae watched his partner’s panicked dissolution with something like contempt, even as the liquid hands of the lake began to descend upon him. He would not scatter. He would not run. His art demanded a clean ending. He looked across the water, his cracked face a mask of cold fury, his void-black eyes locking onto Pip. With a final, monumental effort, he raised one hand, not to attack, but to make a single, precise gesture. He was not trying to erase Pip. He was trying to erase their connection. He aimed his will at the bond between the pixie and the lake, intending to sever it with the surgical precision of a scalpel. *“The signal will end,”* his final, fractured thought stabbed into Pip’s mind, a promise of eternal, clinical silence.

But the lake was faster. Before the Fae’s final spell could find its mark, the two immense, watery hands closed. They did not crush him in a physical sense. They enveloped him. For a single, terrible moment, he was encased in a prison of pure, living water, a tomb of elemental force. The turquoise light blazed, and from within the watery sphere, the Fae’s form was subjected to the full, unbridled, ancient power Pip had unleashed. He was not just being pressed; he was being remembered. The lake forced into his being the feeling of every shipwreck, the terror of every drowning man, the slow, grinding eternity of water against rock. The artist of emptiness was force-fed an infinity of sensation, an ocean of messy, chaotic, vibrant, and terrifying life. His silent, empty core could not bear the noise. A silent, black light flashed within the watery tomb, and then the Fae's form simply… broke. He shattered like a glass statue filled with ink, his essence imploding, the void within him collapsing under the sheer, overwhelming weight of existence. The moment the Fae shattered, the focal point for Pip’s rage vanished. The immense, telepathic weight of the lake, which had been channeled through him, suddenly had nowhere to go. It recoiled back into him with the force of a tidal wave hitting a cliff face. The power that had been his weapon turned on its wielder. An agony beyond all description ripped through him, and the world dissolved into a roaring, green-lit chaos. His mind, which had held an ocean, was now just a teacup in a flood. He saw nothing, felt nothing but the crushing, final weight of the lake trying to pull him down, to claim its exhausted, broken instrument and drag him into the silent, waiting silt. He had won the battle, but his friend was dying, and he was being dragged into the deep.

The darkness that claimed him was not an absence of light, but an overabundance of being. Pip’s consciousness, a bright, singular spark, was plunged into the vast, cold, collective ‘I’ of Lake Michigan. He was no longer a pixie; he was a water molecule in an ocean of memory. He felt the slow, patient scrape of retreating glaciers, the blind, silent life of creatures in the abyssal dark, the fury of a thousand storms, and the crushing weight of every drop of water from shore to shore, surface to silt. Pip’s dissolving consciousness latched onto it, a drowning man grabbing a piece of floating debris. He pulled. It was the hardest thing he had ever done, a fight not against an external enemy, but against the blissful, terrifying oblivion of becoming part of something larger. He pulled himself out of the collective ‘we’ of the water, out of the memories of storms and shipwrecks, and back into the singular, small, fragile ‘I’ that was his. The roaring of the depths receded, the pressure eased, and the vast, ancient mind of the lake, its rage sated and its enemy vanquished, sank back into its deep, watery slumber.

Pip gasped, a ragged, shuddering intake of air, and found himself lying on the cold, wet stone of the steps. Barnaby was a ruin. The solid, fluffy form of the Horned Dorset was now a puddled, semi-translucent mass of greyish mist. The proud, cirrus-cloud horns were cracked and dull, and the internal warmth was gone, replaced by a deep, unnatural cold. But the worst was the wound. Barnaby’s dewdrop eyes were half-closed, their light a faint, fading glimmer. He let out a tiny puff of vapor from his nose, a weak, pained cloud that failed to form any shape before dissipating. His way of saying, *I’m still here. But not for long.*

Panic, cold and sharp, seized Pip. He placed his hands on either side of the terrible wound, his mind scrabbling for a mending charm, the simple weaving of light and intention that was his trade. He drew a breath and began to chant the soft, clicking words of the Old Tongue, pouring every last dreg of his own battered life force into the spell. The same magic that had created the rift in the world was now eating his best friend from the inside out, and he was powerless to stop it. He had saved his world, and the price was everything in it that mattered.

## Chapter 9

The silence that followed the lake’s victory was more profound than any the Hollow could have crafted. It was a silence born of exhaustion, of a world holding its breath. Pip knelt on the cold stone, the city he had saved glittering behind him like a chest of indifferent jewels. He looked at the ruin of his friend, and the victory felt like a colossal, bitter lie. The janitor had saved the building, but the heart had been ripped out of his own small home. The void-wound in Barnaby’s center was a perfect, silent scream, a hole not just in a cloud-sheep, but in the fabric of Pip’s world. His own magic, a thing of mending and making, was useless against this clean, absolute un-making. The wound did not heal; it hungered.

He cradled Barnaby’s dissipating form, the once-warm fleece now a cold, thin mist that slipped through his fingers. A desperate, frantic inventory of options raced through his exhausted mind. He could not go back to the Glimmer; the old courts would see Barnaby not as a creature to be saved, but as a dangerous contamination to be “cleansed,” and they would see Pip’s city as a chaotic territory to be brought to heel. He thought of the Librarian, but the memory was a fresh wound of its own. What could he possibly offer the archival golem that was worth more than the joy of flight? His sorrow? His fear? He had a horrifying feeling the Librarian would accept, cataloging his grief and leaving him an empty shell. He had only one option left. A cynical, grasping, utterly untrustworthy, and completely indispensable dealer in impossible things.

“Hold on, pal,” he whispered to the fading light in Barnaby’s eyes, the words a desperate prayer. “Just hold on.” He gathered the wounded cloud-sheep into his arms. It was like trying to hold smoke. Barnaby’s form was barely cohesive, a cold, heavy fog that threatened to drift apart with every gust of wind. Pip wrapped his own arms, his jacket, and his very will around his friend, trying to physically hold him together as he launched himself into the air. The flight was an agony. He flew low and slow, a frantic, limping progress through the city’s canyons. The vibrant life of Chicago, the city he had just fought and bled for, was a torturous mockery. The joyful chatter spilling from a late-night diner, the warm glow of a thousand apartment windows, the rumble of a train carrying people home—each one was a stab of pain, a reminder of the simple, living warmth that was draining out of the precious burden in his arms.

He landed in the grimy West Loop alley with a stumble, his legs barely holding him. He didn’t hesitate. He kicked open the door to “FINDS,” the discordant chime a shriek of alarm in the dead of night. The shop was a tomb of clutter and silence. Silas was behind the counter, polishing a silver locket with a soft cloth, his head bowed. He didn’t look up. “We’re closed,” he rasped, his voice full of dry finality. “Whatever war you just won, the spoils are your own. I want no part of it.”

“I’m not here to trade, Silas,” Pip’s voice broke, a ragged sound of pure desperation. He staggered forward and, with an infinite, heartbreaking gentleness, laid Barnaby on the dusty, worn floorboards of the shop. The sight was grotesque, a tragedy staged in a junk shop. The once-proud cloud-sheep was a puddle of cold, grey mist, his form barely recognizable, the perfect, hissing circle of nothingness at his center a stark, black wound against the dark wood. “I’m here to beg.”

For the first time since Pip had known him, Silas was shocked into silence. He stopped polishing the locket. His slate-grey eyes widened behind his spectacles as he peered over the counter at the dying creature on his floor. He rose slowly, his joints cracking like dry twigs, and walked around the counter, his usual predatory grace replaced by a wary, almost academic caution. He knelt, not too close, and studied the void-wound, his head tilted. His nose wrinkled, as if smelling something profoundly offensive. “Stars and stones,” he breathed, a genuine curse. “You didn’t just fight them. You brought a piece of their work home with you. This… this is a contamination. This is an anchor for their philosophy. It’s not just killing your pet, pixie. It’s unmaking him.”

Silas stood up, his face grim, the shopkeeper replacing the scholar. “Get it out of my shop. It’s bad for the metaphysics.” Pip looked up, his face a mask of pleading. “I can’t. You’re the only one who would know. Is there a cure? A counter-spell? Anything?” Silas let out a dry, humorless chuckle. “A counter-spell? You can’t counter nothing. You can’t mend a hole. You can only fill it. And you can’t fill a hole made of pure absence with… something. That’s like trying to patch a shadow with sunlight. It doesn’t work. The void consumes it.” He paced a short, agitated line, his eyes darting between Pip’s desperate face and the dying creature on the floor. “No. To fill a hole like that, you need a different kind of magic. You need potential. The absolute, unblemished potential for something to exist.”

He stopped pacing and fixed Pip with a sharp, calculating gaze. His dealer’s instinct was returning, sniffing out the shape of an epic, and therefore profitable, bargain. “There is one artifact I know of that might work. An object of pure, conceptual power. Its value is… incalculable.” He leaned closer, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. “They call it the Unstruck Match. It was crafted in the wake of the Great Fire, by a watchmaker who dabbled in thaumaturgy. He took a single match from a batch intended to light the first gas lamp of the rebuilt city and imbued it not with fire, but with the infinite, conceptual *potential* for fire. It is the beginning of every bonfire, the seed of every hearth, the promise of every candle. It doesn’t hold a flame; it holds the idea of *all flame*. Its magic is the ultimate ‘could be,’ the perfect opposite to the void’s absolute ‘is not.’”

Pip’s heart seized on the single thread of hope. “Where is it? Do you have it?” Silas laughed again, a dry, rustling sound. “Have it? Little pixie, if I had the Unstruck Match, I wouldn’t be sitting in this dusty tomb. I would own the sun. No, it was lost decades ago. Stolen, fell from a ship, who knows. All I know is who has it now.” He pointed a long, bony finger eastward, toward the lake. “There’s an old water intake crib out there, the one they call the Four-Mile.
